column13: Added font replacement & two improved fonts
column20:
New 'fontreplace' command allows multiple PBMs in one file, so an entire font can be replaced with one command.
md380-gfx changed to use ASCII PBM glyphs (instead of binary) for easier hand editing. Hint: replace all '0' with '.', then modify font text file, then replace '.' back with '0' to use with md380-gfx
Two sample files are provided - large and small latin fonts.  Tested with v2.32; should work with others.

Hi John,
an test branch... that's used your new font
https://github.com/aeickho/md380tools/tree/usersdb_in_spi_flash
With no users.csv in spiflash test chars will be displayed instead of the transmitter status info.
To Import the users data:
wc -c < db/users.csv > data ; cat db/users.csv >> data  # generate data file
and flash the data file to the spiflash with:
./md380-tool spiflashwrite data.txt 0x100000

column20: Just a little script to aumatically update ad format users list, removing unused column
column21:
I did something similar by modifying the user.csv on the fly in the Makefile
flashdb:
        cat db/users.csv | sed 's/\s+,/,/g' | sed 's/,\s+/,/g' | cut -d',' -f1-3,5-6 >/tmp/users.csv
        wc -c < /tmp/users.csv > data ; cat /tmp/users.csv >> data
        ./md380-tool spiflashwrite data 0x100000

which cuts out the (often empty) nickname field and trims off the last couple fields.  On the radio it no longer cuts off the data while the person is talking now.

column13: Better wording for ids that are not in users.csv
column20:
Sometimes (like TG 9998 Parrot for example) calls come in that are not
in the dmr-marc database. Other times new users arrive that aren't in
our loaded database yet. We shouldn't imply that the users.csv is not
loaded correctly. We should just state that the user isn't found in the
memory.
column21:
Sometimes (like TG 9998 Parrot for example) calls come in that are not
in the dmr-marc database. Other times new users arrive that aren't in
our loaded database yet. We shouldn't imply that the users.csv is not
loaded correctly. We should just state that the user isn't found in the
memory.

column13: Rename files to allow importation as a module
column20:
The md380-* file naming scheme breaks Python module import.
Fixing this would be helpful for the Chirp driver to allow upload and download.
This commit renames them to a md380_*.py scheme, allowing import like md380tools.md380_dfu
It also fixes all references I could find to the affected files.
column21:

column21:
No objection to changing the filenames, but it'll be a hassle for everyone involved, so let's be careful to do the renaming exactly right on the first try.
We should avoid underscores in executable names, even just for scripts. This might also be a good time to switch to varargs for interpreting the command line arguments.

column13: Rename files to allow importation as a module
column20:
The md380-* file naming scheme breaks Python module import.
Fixing this would be helpful for the Chirp driver to allow upload and download.
This commit renames them to a md380_*.py scheme, allowing import like md380tools.md380_dfu
It also fixes all references I could find to the affected files.
column21:
Agree on hassle and getting it right the first time.
Only reason I went with underscores is because it was closest to the current system that was compatible with importing, I'm not attached to the scheme at all.
If not underscores, not symlinks, and not dashes:

md380tools.py, md380dfu.py, md380gfx.py, md380fw.py
mdtools.py, mddfu.py, mdgfx.py, mdfw.py
380tools.py, 380dfu.py, 380gfx.py, 380fw.py
tools.py, dfu.py, gfx.py, fw.py
something else?

I can't say I'm convinced of any of the above. The first set and last set seem least offensive.
I'd love to just symlink a nice name to the python files and commit those, except that doesn't seem to be well supported on Git for Windows platforms. I tried to just symlink a python-import friendly name pointed at the current names, except I ran into "Too many levels of symlinks" issues.

column21: What I've done in my own Python projects is to move all logic (usually including main()) out of the script and into a module, leaving only the argument parsing and a call to main in the non-.py script.

column13: Keep executable names, let module imports work
column20:
Keep these names?
Executables are the same names, modules are md380_<thing>.py.
I was able to successfully use these to write a modified boot logo, make the firmware, and flash it. I then read the radio SMS messages and dmesg to make sure md380-tool still worked as well.
Good names? Bad names? Bugs?
This is the successor to #101

column21: The USB driver for the radio gets replaced by one for libusb-win32 in order for md380tools to be able to communicate with it. In order to use the Tytera CPS, you will need to disable or remove the driver in device manager. I am in the process of writing a CPS that uses md380tools to communicate but it is a long way off at the moment due to other commitments.

column13: First iteration of improved firmware downloader/unpacker makefile
column20:
This updates the firmware downloader to

download firmware images from archive.org, as VA3XPR has started requiring newsletter subscription
download all versions of the firmware images
unpack all versions of the firmware
automatically unwrap all versions of the firmware
only delete non-downloaded files during a normal "make clean", to prevent accidental loss of data

It also updates the 2.032 patcher to look in the new location for the firmware image.
A Phase 2 would provide a more generalized firmware download and unpack Makefile, probably pulling file information (locations, paths inside the zip, firmware checksums) from a text file listing this information.

column13: First iteration of improved firmware downloader/unpacker makefile
column20:
This updates the firmware downloader to

download firmware images from archive.org, as VA3XPR has started requiring newsletter subscription
download all versions of the firmware images
unpack all versions of the firmware
automatically unwrap all versions of the firmware
only delete non-downloaded files during a normal "make clean", to prevent accidental loss of data

It also updates the 2.032 patcher to look in the new location for the firmware image.
A Phase 2 would provide a more generalized firmware download and unpack Makefile, probably pulling file information (locations, paths inside the zip, firmware checksums) from a text file listing this information.

column13: Add Reflector IDs from Brandmeister network to user DB
column20:
This fetches the Reflector DB from the Brandmeister network and basically integrates the Reflector IDs into usres.csv. I used perl to parse the file in order to not break compatibility.
As the file does not contain a newline at the end I manually added one together with ID 5000 which replies with a status info if sent out on a BM link.
column21:
This fetches the Reflector DB from the Brandmeister network and basically integrates the Reflector IDs into usres.csv. I used perl to parse the file in order to not break compatibility.
As the file does not contain a newline at the end I manually added one together with ID 5000 which replies with a status info if sent out on a BM link.

column13: Add separate file with special IDs / TGs
column20: There are some IDs / TGs out there that are currently not available in a central database or the like. Examples are 5000 for Status information or 262997 for echo/parrot function on the German BM master. As an interims solution I put them into a separate file that is merged into the users.csv.

ACTION=="add", SUBSYSTEM=="usb", ATTR{idVendor}=="0483", ATTR{idProduct}=="df11", GROUP="dialout", MODE="0660"

column21:
Howdy y'all,
It's not so much a matter of security as that we are only supporting hobbyists on mostly single user systems. Ham radio largely functions because folks agree not to be jerks to one another, and even though our repeaters could easily be jammed we rarely suffer more than the occasional troll.
If we ever support the radio on multi-user systems, such as a club server, then we'll include a section in the configuration guide for it.  For now, I'd rather not complicate the installation at the cost of more support requests.  666 permissions work well for software defined radios, and they should remain the default here.  The permissions can be reduced as needed on multi user machines.
Closing this issue.
73 from Buda,
-Travis HA/KK4VCZ

column13: Added: boot screen selection; radio name auto configuration; dynamic bootscreen
column20:
This is three related additions packed into one.
First and foremost: the radio name is now set in the config from an automatic lookup in the usersdb whenever the DMR ID is changed. This means that peeps should be able to pass around codeplugs and never have to open them in a CPS. This change is set in memory, in the config, and in the codeplug flash on changes, and restored at boot just like the dmrid.
Secondly: The top and bottom lines of the stock text splash are now automatically populated with the DMR ID and the Radio Name. This is something that was requested by a user in the irc channel.
Lastly: the addition of a menu item to disable the boot demo. For one I prefer the radio to boot as fast as possible, and for the second removing the demo brings back the boot chime. It would be good to add the version and credits somewhere else, but I couldn't find how to get the right menu pane to open, so it'll be for another time.

First and foremost: the radio name is now set in the config from an automatic lookup in the usersdb whenever the DMR ID is changed. This means that peeps should be able to pass around codeplugs and never have to open them in a CPS. This change is set in memory, in the config, and in the codeplug flash on changes, and restored at boot just like the dmrid.
Secondly: The top and bottom lines of the stock text splash are now automatically populated with the DMR ID and the Radio Name. This is something that was requested by a user in the irc channel.
Lastly: the addition of a menu item to disable the boot demo. For one I prefer the radio to boot as fast as possible, and for the second removing the demo brings back the boot chime. It would be good to add the version and credits somewhere else, but I couldn't find how to get the right menu pane to open, so it'll be for another time.
column21: Yeah I saw that, but gfx.h is indeed included properly.

column21: FYI/FWIW and for further documentation: the addresses used for keypressed, keycode, etc on the S release contain at the very minimum: keypad lock, and scan mode... as those two are triggered by running the trace_keyb() routines unmodified (hence the #ifdef - until these symbols are found).

column20:
Creation of a sub menu to select boot options.
Removed "quick" demo mode, it was quite useless.
Boot Splash can now be selected between: manual (default, code plug data), callsign+dmrid, or callsign+name (the latter two are only available when userscsv == 1).
Saving of radio name from the userscsv is now only triggered with userscsv == 1.

column21:
Hello Travis,

Nice to hear from you for the first time. Unfortunately I only have an
RT3, and none of the fellows around has a GPS unit.
I noticed a small bug in the implementation ("zero" in the config
structure, leaving the operator with an all-black screen that makes it
difficult to enter the MD380Tools menu at all).
Does it cause a much of work for you and the core devs if I "request a
pull" again with a slighly modified version ?

I considered this: If we had a of "sizeof( addl_config )" stored in the
first byte of struct addl_config itself,
any new application would have the chance to find a parameter was
already set the previously installed firmware
(because "global_addl_config.my_size >= sizeof( addl_config )"),
and if not (size stored in the SPI flash smaller than the size in the
new firmware),
populate its own, new member (e.g. backlight_intensities) with a
meaningful default.

In this case, the set idle backlight to '1', and the active backlight to
'5', or similar.

Unfortunately this is incompatible as you noted to newbies (because the
byte at offset zero is already used for 'crc').
Or am I missing a point, and 'crc' in the first byte would automagically
detect a size mismatch, and fill the entire struct with zeroes ?

Greetings from Germany,
   Wolf DL4YHF .

Hi Sven and all,
I temporarily switched back to the earlier "GPIO bitbanging PWM". By the
time you read this it should be on the 'Wolf-DL4YHF' repo, and (compiled
into dl4yhf_weak_backlight_experiment.zip/experiment_PWM_via_GPIO.bin)
on my page at qsl.net .
The 'GPIO-variant' produces a PWM with only 74 Hz. The UART-variant uses
220 Hz (approximately).

I noticed that both variants suffer from the same problem in the menu
("Backlt low" + "Backlt high") :

The 'blue disc' that marks the currently selected item doesn't properly
follow the vertical scrolling position.
Only the blue marker bar marks the current setting (before navigating
with the cursor keys).
The same effect could sometimes be seen in other menus (iirc the date
format selection). Didn't look it up yet, maybe there's a topic already
existing for this in the google group.

Guess we should postpone any attempt to merge my temporary branch; I
need a better understand how the menu functions are supposed to work.

73,  Wolf .

column21:
Hi Sven and all 'dimmed backlight testers',

I have reduced the UART baudrate so the PWM frequency is 104 Hz now.
It's in my temporary branch on Github, but also (for convenience) in the
zip file at
   http://www.qsl.net/dl4yhf/RT3/dl4yhf_weak_backlight_experiment.zip

There are two variants of the backlight at the momemt, one producing the
PWM "via GPIO" and one "via UART".
The PWM frequency of the UART-variant is 104 Hz now, the GPIO variant
produces 74 Hz ( SysTick frequency, 666.6 Hz / 9 ).

If the UART variant still doesn't work on your radio please try the GPIO
variant, from the zip archive:
     experiment_PWM_via_GPIO.bin .

As before, both are ONLY for RT3 / MD380 (non-GPS). I added support for
the GPS devices, based on the S13.020 firmware, including the necessary
patches in the 'merge' scripts, but I cannot test them.

All these are contained in the Github repo now. In the repo, a switch is
already set to compile the interrupt handler (SysTick_Handler) for the
UART variant because (unlike the GPIO variant) it doesn't flicker at all.

Besides these pending tests, the temporary 'backlight' branch is ready
for being merged into the master.
I would prefer to have it merged back before beginning to play with the
microphone gain and audio signal paths.

Greetings from snow-covered Germany,
   Wolf .

column21:
Hi Travis,

Yes I also think the existing hook (which btw was the only one i saw,
already existing) is possibly the wrong one.

Besides that, the rest of the patch for the dimmed backlight works
nicely, on two different radios (I tried it on one which never had a
patched firmware loaded before, and the default settings work properly now).

In the past days I dug deeply into the original firmware to find the
right hook (my bet is in the 'Start' - task) but there is one remaining
concern:
We possibly need to initialize "our" interrupt handlers twice (which is
ugly but seems unavoidable):

- first *before* Tytera's SystemInit() & Co, to have the backlight (and
other interrupt services) enabled during "our" early display ..
scrolling bitmap on the welcome screen, etc

- a second time *after* Tytera's ResetHandler(), SystemInit(), etc,
because those functions and anything called from there will possibly
'undo' any on-chip peripheral initialisation, via the RCC's "peripheral
reset register". Many Cortex startup functions I've seen over the years
leave "nothing to fate", and reset almost everything (via the RCC, which
is simply done by writing a couple of ONEs into those registers).

We will sooner or later experience similar when integrating Morse code
output in our own interrupt handlers.. it's of my next projects
(providing the morse output; retrieving the text of the currently
selected channel is another story - too difficult for me at the moment).

So here's my suggestion: Find out where to call our init function
(applet/src/irq_handlers.c : IRQ_Init), and merge any 'future'
interrupt-handler-initialisation into that module.

Cheers,
   Wolf .

Only settings of "Top held" seems to hazzle with "Top pressed", a long(er) press on the key calls the short press function, but this is not a showstopper for now I think.

column13: Added functions to side programmable buttons. Also broke out unused TIM12 interrupt.
column20:
Added ability to set side buttons to our own functions
Added first new side button function: enable/disable backlight
Broke out TIM12 interrupt to be used for our own functions, however it is unused as of now.
To change sidebutton function:
./md380-dfu read codeplug.bin
./md380-codeplug sidebutton ? (for usage)
./md380-dfu write codeplug.bin
column21:
Cross check with the Tyt CPS show, all assignments are fine. I have learned, you are using "unassigned" for backlight toggle and "vox" for the Zone increment.
The long press on "Bottom Held" is working fine, only the "Top Held" seems to need another key assignment, will look for it when finished my latest own changes.

column21:
Regarding the held function muddling with the short press, I was noticing that last night too. That will take a little more investigation. I don't believe my code would interfere with the factory functions like that. I will test on original firmware.
As for the CPS software, I (ab)use the factory firmware codeplug locatio, so CPS will probably report the button as unassigned when in reality it is one of our custom functions. However, the vox vs zone increment I will look in to. That must be a bug on my part.

column21:
In the meantime I made some extended tests with 3 MD390/G available here. The only conflict seems to affect scanmode. When scanmode enabled, the long keypress doesn't work, but this seems to be caused by the original firmware.
I did implement your side-buttons fork and my last netmon changes from my latest PR all into a single fork and were using both on the 3 testradios without problems for the last 2 days. I really like your feature, this gives another benefit to this nice radio.
Together with Wolf's modification of backlight dim, it would be nice, to use one of the sidebuttons to toggle the backlight by short press from a maximum value stored in setup within 2-3 few steps to off by repetitive button pushes.

button reporting that you saw in the CPS software. I grabbed all my values
straight from codeplugs written with version 1.32.

That's fine about the fork. We can make one large merge.

But that's a great idea with Wolf. I'll work with him and we can get a new
function added. Probably after both of these PRs go through.

column21: Found it thanks. I thought I had the most recent software, but I found CPS 1.36 on a different site than the tyterra site. Oh well. There are two different functions that change the zone. CPS 1.32 had zone increment, which just incremented the zone, Zone toggle toggles between the first 4 zones with beeps indicating what zone is selected. The part that gets screwy is zone toggle replaced zone increment in CPS. I have included both functions in the menu because one might work better for someones situation and for backwards compatibility reasons. Also added the battery indicator function available from CPS 1.36. I guess that beeps up to 3 times indicating the current battery level. Thanks Mike. That should be about it for this assuming S13 functionality works as expected.

column21: and remove some unneeded whitespaces

column20:
Hello!
Neat project!  I did some cleanup and hopefully improved Python3 support as read through the code.  The big changes that I did were:

Updated Print calls
Removed semicolons at end of lines (not necessary in Python.  Your C is showing haha üòâ )
Comparison to None should be "is" or "is not" instead of "==" or "!="
No mixing Tabs and Spaces
Removed unused import statements
Whitespace
Augmented assigments were appropriate (i.e. i = i + 1 -> i += 1
Removed xrange in favor of range.  The places were it was being used didn't seem like they had a huge memory footprint and it allowed the code to run in Python3.
Add encoding declarations to the tops of the Python files

I realize this is a a huge pull request but it is all pretty lowly janitorial work.  If you see anything weird let me know or have any questions I am happy to answer them.

column21:
As far as I can see, key "5", that is in discussion to be swapped with currently unused/new assigned key "2" has been introduced on Oct, 7th with PR "syslog tail scrolling" #0277044.
The layout makes no difference to me, cause in my own fork I'm using another key layout since introducing netmon4, when we had this discussion first time.
But take a few minutes and let's have a look at the current keyboard & functions:
+-----+-----+-----+-----+
!  1  !  2  !  3  !  *  " 
+-----+-----+-----+-----+
!  4  !  5  !  6  !  0  " 
+-----+-----+-----+-----+
!  7  !  8  !  9  !  #  " 
+-----+-----+-----+-----+ 

1 - SMS-Test
2 - Netmon5  (new 01/2017)
3 - Copy dst to contact (new 11/2016)
4 - Netmon4 (new 11/2016)
5 - clear syslog (new 10/2016)
6 - syslog dump
7 - Netmon off
8 - Netmon1
9 - Netmon2
'# - Netmon3
To be honest, my suggest for a clean UI and (fmpov) better handling (for right-handed users):
1 - SMS-Test
2 - remain spare
3 - Copy dst to contact (this is nice assigned with the arrow down key above as a hint symbol!)
4 - Netmon4
5 - Netmon5 *
6 - syslog dump
0 - clear syslog *
7 - Netmon1 *
8 - Netmon2 *
9 - Netmon3 *
'# - Netmon off *
'* - reordered keys (7,8,9,# will only wrap around 1 position)
Only one key, "clear syslog" really moves it position from "5" to "0", Netmon5 is new, the bottom line only swaps its order.
The Zero-key "Null" will null/clear the syslog, other keys swapped remain in the same function blocks without unintentional causing a function or deleting something.
The right column will be used to clear or exit from a function (like the red special key above it), the left 3 columns activate or display something.

column13: adding netmon5 and latest changes including #652, #663, #674
column20:
I have merged my PR with already Clay's latest PR included due to extended testing with MD390/G.
Now, due to the delay of several PR's and my continously development on some of the latest PR's I have included my keyb.c into this fork.
Please take a second and let's have a look at my suggest of a new keyboard & functions layout:
+-----+-----+-----+-----+
!  1  !  2  !  3  !  *  " 
+-----+-----+-----+-----+
!  4  !  5  !  6  !  0  " 
+-----+-----+-----+-----+
!  7  !  8  !  9  !  #  " 
+-----+-----+-----+-----+ 

Current official keyboard assignment:
1 - SMS-Test
2 - Netmon5 (new 01/2017)
3 - Copy dst to contact (new 11/2016)
4 - Netmon4 (new 11/2016)
5 - clear syslog (new 10/2016)
6 - syslog dump
7 - Netmon off
8 - Netmon1
9 - Netmon2
'# - Netmon3
My suggest for a clean UI and (fmpov) better handling (for right-handed users):
1 - SMS-Test
2 - spare
3 - Copy dst to contact (this is nice assigned with the arrow down key above as a hint symbol!)
4 - Netmon4 (lastheard calls)
5 - Netmon5 *  (lastheard call&channel)
6 - Netmon6 *  (lastheard channel)
7 - Netmon1 *
8 - Netmon2 *
9 - Netmon3 *
'* - syslog dump *
0 - clear syslog *
'# - Netmon off *
'* - reordered keys (7,8,9,# will only wrap around 1 position)
Only two keys, "syslog dump" (old:6 new:*) and "clear syslog" (old:5 new:0) move positions, Netmon5&6 are new, the bottom line only wraps around its order.
The Zero-key "Null" will null/clear the syslog, other keys swapped remain in the same function blocks without unintentional causing a function or deleting something.
The right column will be used to clear or exit from a function (like the red special key above it), the left 3 columns activate or display something.

Now, due to the delay of several PR's and my continously development on some of the latest PR's I have included my keyb.c into this fork.
Please take a second and let's have a look at my suggest of a new keyboard & functions layout:
+-----+-----+-----+-----+
!  1  !  2  !  3  !  *  " 
+-----+-----+-----+-----+
!  4  !  5  !  6  !  0  " 
+-----+-----+-----+-----+
!  7  !  8  !  9  !  #  " 
+-----+-----+-----+-----+ 

Current official keyboard assignment:
1 - SMS-Test
2 - Netmon5 (new 01/2017)
3 - Copy dst to contact (new 11/2016)
4 - Netmon4 (new 11/2016)
5 - clear syslog (new 10/2016)
6 - syslog dump
7 - Netmon off
8 - Netmon1
9 - Netmon2
'# - Netmon3
My suggest for a clean UI and (fmpov) better handling (for right-handed users):
1 - SMS-Test
2 - spare
3 - Copy dst to contact (this is nice assigned with the arrow down key above as a hint symbol!)
4 - Netmon4 (lastheard calls)
5 - Netmon5 *  (lastheard call&channel)
6 - Netmon6 *  (lastheard channel)
7 - Netmon1 *
8 - Netmon2 *
9 - Netmon3 *
'* - syslog dump *
0 - clear syslog *
'# - Netmon off *
'* - reordered keys (7,8,9,# will only wrap around 1 position)
Only two keys, "syslog dump" (old:6 new:*) and "clear syslog" (old:5 new:0) move positions, Netmon5&6 are new, the bottom line only wraps around its order.
The Zero-key "Null" will null/clear the syslog, other keys swapped remain in the same function blocks without unintentional causing a function or deleting something.
The right column will be used to clear or exit from a function (like the red special key above it), the left 3 columns activate or display something.
column21:
Hi Travis,
there are two new LH screens (netmon5&6) that extend the functionallity of my former netmon4/LH-list.
Due to the fact, that I currently have no scrolling implemented, netmon5 gives you at the end of the LH log in line 9 the latest channel name additionally to logged call, on which the latest activity has been monitored and a page counter.
Netmon6 logs no callsigns but channel names on which activity has been monitored.
Both functions have been realized with slog (station log) & clog (=channel log) to be able to clear the logscreens independently (may be integrated in one multifunctional log in future revisions).
The features have been tested for a few weeks, on channels or during times like the weekly WW net on TG91 and in scanning mode these new features are very helpful, because netmon4 is currently limited to only 10 entries of last heard stations.
73 from Hannover/Celle region,
Mike

column13: Add curl retry persistence to help with sluggish network connectivity
column20:
Add options on curl for user.bin downloads to help avoid empty downloads on fail. Seems to help recover when on 3G/4G LTE links with latency issues. Users seem to get 0 byte downloads of dmrmarc.tmp mostly, and not much UI to tell them what happened. First I changed out curl for wget, which immediately worked when curl was failing... however let's use retry switches on curl first: timeout 8 wget "http://www.dmr-marc.net/cgi-bin/trbo-database/datadump.cgi?table=users&format=csv&header=0" -O ~/md380tools/db/retry.tmp cat ~/md380tools/db/retry.tmp | perl -pe 's,
,,' >~/md380tools/db/dmrmarc.tmp Warren Merkel, KD4Z

column20: Add ability to store changes on S13.020 and display the currently selected backlight timeout.
column21:
I've tested it on a MD-380G (with GPS) and a MD-380 without GPS, so it should work on a MD-390 without GPS (if there is such a thing) with the D13.020 firmware.
On the non-GPS units, the selection was already saved in flash, this was only missing for the GPS-models (which is added by the first patch in this PR).
I also don't know what exactly triggers the blue discs to work

column20: Add ability to store changes on S13.020 and display the currently selected backlight timeout.
column21:
The "blue disc" usually called "radio button" in programming IDE's is only a visual marker for the selected entry. But you can prove very simply that storing the selected setup works fine, when using the sidebutton modification with it's long selection list.
When you recall a setting, the correct menu entry is listed active, but missing the radiobutton marker. I've also had a brief look on this a few weeks ago but working on some netmon enhancements since that time. As far as I noticed, it works fine for the first 4 entries of a list (like most factory settings) but is corrupt for md380tools setup options with more. May be a corrupt index or value overflow.
I've included this patch by stargo also into my fork with Clays sidebutton menu and an additional improvement (#34054c1) to that giving detailed feedback info when saving selection and the latest netmon6 channel list in my latest fork (but be aware, my keyb layout is slightly different (see PR #663).
But currently it looks like we have some PR's in queue due to Appveyor issues during the past weeks.

column13: Increase sanity check on userdb size for find_dmr_user() to 5 MB
column20:
To avoid "ID unknown" message when userdb is over 3279629 bytes.
My post build processing is now reaching past this limit, due to first
name substitution into the now missing "nickname" field from dmr-marc.
This shows up in the Firstname field of the display.  Makes all lookups pretty.
Discussion: Was there anything magic about the prior value of 3279629?
It doesn't look like anything lives above that boundary, all the way to
top.
Warren, KD4Z

column13: backlight control modified, suspected CPU reset when turned on too early
column20:
SysTick_Handler now "waits" until the original firmware turns backlight on, then takes over control, and starts dimming.
Old backlight control may have turned BL on too early, when power supply had not ramped up completely (drawing too much current, depending on BL configuration).
No need to initialize from splash_hook() anymore (which may have been "too early"..)
Details in irq_handlers.c .

column13: New netmon5/netmon6, fixed typos, backlight submenu, added talker alias to status and usercsv disp
column20:
Additional change notes to this build:
changes to md380tools setup:

Submenu: "Show call" (former userscsv): select source of callsign display (CPS, UserDB, TalkerAlias)
Submenu: "Date format": new option "TalkerAlias", renamed "Alt Status" -> "Lastheard"
Submenu: "Sidebuttons" if you change an option, your setting is confirmed instead only "Function set"
Submenu: "Backlight": options Level low, high, timer moved to this seperate submenu

To enable TA in statusline, select option "Talker Alias" from setup menu #3.
To enable full screen TA display select option "Talk Alias" or "TA & UserDB" from setup menu #4.
Due to the legacy keyb layout, the netmon screens are spreaded around, you found them on:
key "4" - netmon4 - lastheard and TA (if received)
key "2" - netmon5 - lastheard + LH channel and page status mark >>>>> channel << #n after 9 lines
key "0" - netmon6 - channel LH list, shows, where activity was received (helpful on longer monitoring)
2017-02-25:

solving build issue with D02.032 in netmon.c

2017-02-24:

solving all merge conflicts and returning to legacy keyb layout

2017-02-18:

add talker alias option to date format submenu (additionally to alt status)
show talker alias on status line if received valid info
display users.csv entry with talker alias in name info (line below callsign & name)
The Zero-key "Null" will null/clear the syslog, other keys swapped remain in the same function blocks without unintentional causing a function or deleting something.

2017-02-17:

New netmon5 shows mixed channel name (when channel changes) / lastheard calls / lh page count
New netmon6 shows last channels with activities (to give you an idea where your lastheard were RX)
Fixed typo in addl_config.c (md380_create_main_menu_entry)
Organized all backlight settings in a seperate submenu in md380tools menu instead of 3 main entries

Hi Simon,
only did, what Travis asked me for in my last PR (#663) which I closed due to many other changes last night:

travisgoodspeed commented 6 days ago
To prepare for a merge, could you please update this branch with the following:
An accurate and complete description in the title and body of the pull request. (Not just comments.)
Resolve the merge conflicts in keyb.c, menu.c, and fixed.csv.
Add comments to slog.c, clog.c, and any other new functions or files.
Keyboard layout changes should probably be in separate pull requests from features, but we'll see what  can be done.
73 from Philly,
KK4VCZ

73 Mike

column13: New netmon5/netmon6, fixed typos, backlight submenu, added talker alias to status and usercsv disp
column20:
Additional change notes to this build:
changes to md380tools setup:

Submenu: "Show call" (former userscsv): select source of callsign display (CPS, UserDB, TalkerAlias)
Submenu: "Date format": new option "TalkerAlias", renamed "Alt Status" -> "Lastheard"
Submenu: "Sidebuttons" if you change an option, your setting is confirmed instead only "Function set"
Submenu: "Backlight": options Level low, high, timer moved to this seperate submenu

To enable TA in statusline, select option "Talker Alias" from setup menu #3.
To enable full screen TA display select option "Talk Alias" or "TA & UserDB" from setup menu #4.
Due to the legacy keyb layout, the netmon screens are spreaded around, you found them on:
key "4" - netmon4 - lastheard and TA (if received)
key "2" - netmon5 - lastheard + LH channel and page status mark >>>>> channel << #n after 9 lines
key "0" - netmon6 - channel LH list, shows, where activity was received (helpful on longer monitoring)
2017-02-25:

solving build issue with D02.032 in netmon.c

2017-02-24:

solving all merge conflicts and returning to legacy keyb layout

2017-02-18:

add talker alias option to date format submenu (additionally to alt status)
show talker alias on status line if received valid info
display users.csv entry with talker alias in name info (line below callsign & name)
The Zero-key "Null" will null/clear the syslog, other keys swapped remain in the same function blocks without unintentional causing a function or deleting something.

2017-02-17:

New netmon5 shows mixed channel name (when channel changes) / lastheard calls / lh page count
New netmon6 shows last channels with activities (to give you an idea where your lastheard were RX)
Fixed typo in addl_config.c (md380_create_main_menu_entry)
Organized all backlight settings in a seperate submenu in md380tools menu instead of 3 main entries
column21: What about all the new functions and submenu's I already added last weekend? No interest to merge my changes ... I did a complete pull/push last weekend with many optimization to LH and netmon4,5,6 features (no more need for slog/clog.c/h etc.).

column21:
Howdy @DL2MF,
Large pull requests take a lot of effort to merge, because so many things have to be tested and verified first.  We can't just hit the "merge" button and hope for the best.
Some remaining issues:

 The keyboard layout changes really have to be in a separate pull request from functional changes.  Even if it's an improvement, folks will complain about the difference, and we need to do any UI changes exactly once to limit confusion.  This is the primary reason why this branch is slow to be merged.
 This branch has conflicts with menu.c and netmon.c.
 This branch breaks some of the talker-alias features in netmon.

73 from New York,
--Travis

I made a full and clean pull last friday night, developed around the TA feature together with Rudy during a telegram chat on friday night. There were no merge conflicts, but then somebody merged Rudy's PR before mine last weekend.
On sunday I implemented the backlight part and put all functions into a submenu, now the same with menu.c during the last 24h hours ...
It was already my second try of this PR I made and I did implement all everything of my changed codeparts again last week. Now the same again due to the preferred changes made later by other people.

I'll revoke the keyb.c and make it supporting legacy layout again
Netmon.c is including all my latest changes (netmon5 and 6) and Rudy's part of TA
the menu.c includes all changes for a backlight submenu and necessary changes for TA selections
display.c includes TA in status line (needs setup from menu.c) and is prepared for new draw_ta_screen for the talker alias display (under development) in RX screen

I'm running this build on 2x MD390G since 1 week successfully, many people did ask me on twitter, when the new functions, that also have been announced by Peter (hamdigitaal.nl) will be available.
Any other idea, how I can successfully support a merge without doing the work from one complete weekend again?

break it up in small parts, make stubs that you replace later so that in the end is all done right.
I guess that small parts can be made quicker and less chance of a conflicting merge.
see http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6217156/break-a-previous-commit-into-multiple-commits
splitting commits
the more people work on the code and the longer your part takes, the bigger is the chance that this happens.

@roelandjansen: We had an very agile development last weekend (sometimes called sprint), resulting in 8 PR's until sunday evening due to many new features. This is, how software development is going on, when merging the changes will not have the speed of development ;-).
But I did wonder during the night from friday to saturday chatting with Rudy, when I submitted the first PR, that PD0ZRY's change within less the 30 minutes (that was the same time prepared in my PR, due to Rudy and I did test TA feature before together) was already merged by Simon, but maybe he didn't notice mine ...  ;-)
Otherwise I had only to submit the keyb.c again with the legacy layout ...
OK, I'll try to fetch some of my features again, but I'll not recode everything again for a 3rd time.
73 Mike, DL2MF

column13: New netmon5/netmon6, fixed typos, backlight submenu, added talker alias to status and usercsv disp
column20:
Additional change notes to this build:
changes to md380tools setup:

Submenu: "Show call" (former userscsv): select source of callsign display (CPS, UserDB, TalkerAlias)
Submenu: "Date format": new option "TalkerAlias", renamed "Alt Status" -> "Lastheard"
Submenu: "Sidebuttons" if you change an option, your setting is confirmed instead only "Function set"
Submenu: "Backlight": options Level low, high, timer moved to this seperate submenu

To enable TA in statusline, select option "Talker Alias" from setup menu #3.
To enable full screen TA display select option "Talk Alias" or "TA & UserDB" from setup menu #4.
Due to the legacy keyb layout, the netmon screens are spreaded around, you found them on:
key "4" - netmon4 - lastheard and TA (if received)
key "2" - netmon5 - lastheard + LH channel and page status mark >>>>> channel << #n after 9 lines
key "0" - netmon6 - channel LH list, shows, where activity was received (helpful on longer monitoring)
2017-02-25:

solving build issue with D02.032 in netmon.c

2017-02-24:

solving all merge conflicts and returning to legacy keyb layout

2017-02-18:

add talker alias option to date format submenu (additionally to alt status)
show talker alias on status line if received valid info
display users.csv entry with talker alias in name info (line below callsign & name)
The Zero-key "Null" will null/clear the syslog, other keys swapped remain in the same function blocks without unintentional causing a function or deleting something.

2017-02-17:

New netmon5 shows mixed channel name (when channel changes) / lastheard calls / lh page count
New netmon6 shows last channels with activities (to give you an idea where your lastheard were RX)
Fixed typo in addl_config.c (md380_create_main_menu_entry)
Organized all backlight settings in a seperate submenu in md380tools menu instead of 3 main entries
column21: Please reduce the size of your PRs, and please PR on a branch in your own repo.

column21:
@DL2MF
Howdy Mike,
Thanks for the cleanup.  I've grabbed this branch and flashed it as both D13 and S13.  I'm able to send and receive calls, but the screen brightness feature seems broken, stuck at full brightness.
Looking closer, it seems the cause is that several hundred lines of irq_handlers.c have been cut in commit 71f0132, including backlight dimming and all of the incoming support for Morse code.  I'm sorry, but I really can't merge this branch.
73 from New York,
--Travis

column21:
Hey Travis,
thanks for working again on my branch, sorry for any inconvenience with this. It was my fault, after pulling a fresh clone on friday, I did copy older irq_handler.c/.h to my md380tools folder. Due to the changes to both files 4 days ago, these additions were lost.
Flashing my radio with the latest build, the screen brightness was working, also changing by the setup was successfully tested.
Hopefully I did now the final repair take both files from your official site back into my repo. Will wait for the CI build process to complete.
73 from Celle, Germany
Mike, DL2MF

column21:
@sijskes:  Such a bad weekend? Keep patient, I were talking about my new added TA screen:

... the TA screen during RX is under heavy development

Due to my added options to the setup, you can select betwenn displaying user information from:

CPS only
UserDB
TalkerAlias
TA + UserDB

The 3rd option is an added screen (draw_ta_screen) where I additionally display some fields from the UserDB and where most DB fields may be removed, when TA is working with more information displayed during RX and option #3 selected.

column21:
@DL2MF I've bean trying you version.
Display options "TalkerAlias" and "TA + UserDB" look the same. Most of the times it doesn't appear with the new look, but with the existing UserDB format. As @w7xm said, country is cut off on the last line.
The netmon5 and netmon6 look nice, with some usefull information.
New option on "Date format" with the "TalkerAlias" work very good.
Resuming... When this PR is accepted, if it really arrive to be, you still have an hard work fixing displays layout.
73's
Paulo - CT2JAY

@it9esi: name is missed ...

I can read "Francesco" from both screens you submitted?
The mixed TA/DB info intentionally will not show/repeat it in the lower part, because most hams (like you) will set TA to name and additional info. Only callsign and country are displayed from the database.
@w7xm:
This build is in use on several radios from my friends (RT3, 3x MD390/G, MD380) without any further issues than already known from other builds without these features.
All of the changes have been documented in detail and I have been working myself hard on this PR, but I have also to wait until merge before continuing any further development (in smaller steps).
Like Travis explained, it may need some more time due to many changes, but new LH modes and TA is affecting due to implementation of some new settings and features several modules.

column13: New netmon5/netmon6, fixed typos, backlight submenu, added talker alias to status and usercsv disp
column20:
Additional change notes to this build:
changes to md380tools setup:

Submenu: "Show call" (former userscsv): select source of callsign display (CPS, UserDB, TalkerAlias)
Submenu: "Date format": new option "TalkerAlias", renamed "Alt Status" -> "Lastheard"
Submenu: "Sidebuttons" if you change an option, your setting is confirmed instead only "Function set"
Submenu: "Backlight": options Level low, high, timer moved to this seperate submenu

To enable TA in statusline, select option "Talker Alias" from setup menu #3.
To enable full screen TA display select option "Talk Alias" or "TA & UserDB" from setup menu #4.
Due to the legacy keyb layout, the netmon screens are spreaded around, you found them on:
key "4" - netmon4 - lastheard and TA (if received)
key "2" - netmon5 - lastheard + LH channel and page status mark >>>>> channel << #n after 9 lines
key "0" - netmon6 - channel LH list, shows, where activity was received (helpful on longer monitoring)
2017-02-25:

solving build issue with D02.032 in netmon.c

2017-02-24:

solving all merge conflicts and returning to legacy keyb layout

2017-02-18:

add talker alias option to date format submenu (additionally to alt status)
show talker alias on status line if received valid info
display users.csv entry with talker alias in name info (line below callsign & name)
The Zero-key "Null" will null/clear the syslog, other keys swapped remain in the same function blocks without unintentional causing a function or deleting something.

2017-02-17:

New netmon5 shows mixed channel name (when channel changes) / lastheard calls / lh page count
New netmon6 shows last channels with activities (to give you an idea where your lastheard were RX)
Fixed typo in addl_config.c (md380_create_main_menu_entry)
Organized all backlight settings in a seperate submenu in md380tools menu instead of 3 main entries
column21: I notice now that no progress has been made? The updates remain so far out. Sorry to have to respect it.

column21:
Hey Travis,
many ppl are asking me for the new functions in my latest build and request for binary images. Until the latest PR has been merged, they can't get them without self-compiling. My own development has also been stopped, because I put a lot of effort into this build, that I won't do again. I stopped the MD446 keyboard support and many other ideas.
To bring this PR to a final decision, I made an ultimate md380tools burn-in-test with my MD390/G, just uploading a 10 minutes video about this to YouTube.
My radio is running this build, flashed 2017-03-04 now in a 24/7 non-stop burn-in-test since 2017-04-07 in permanent operation. That means, the radio was not powered off since more than 1 week - ~200 hours of continous operation.
I've been using this radio excessive a week ago on a trip to FUNK.TAG Kassel operating many repeaters, simplex operation on the exhibition, scanmode the whole day/week from last Sunday to this Saturday, permanently powered ON and put to the dash charger during the night.

The pagecounter #232 yesterday afternoon = 2320 lines logged
There have been recorded > 2000 callsign entries in the Netmon4 - LH list, hundreds of channel entries in the new Netmon6 - Channel list. I've been using the radio on a business trip, in portable operation and at home - many hours RX/TX without any issues, no hang, no stuck, no reboot. To avoid any issues also 3 friends of mine are using a build on MD380 (DL3OBI), RT8 (DF7AH) and another MD390/G (DO5NF) without any trouble and are very lucky with the new features.
Watch the video at: https://youtu.be/1CHz33Db4-Q
73 Mike, DL2MF

column21:
Hi Mike,
That's interesting .. 2000 callsign entries in Netmon4 is impressive,
but doesn't this eat up much of the precious tiny RAM that we have for
our own purposes ? For example, I am playing on an alternative menu,
with an alternative LCD driver (already working, much faster and less
QRM than the sluggish 'gfx'-stuff in the original firmware), but I think
our firmware additions must be very careful as much as memory (RAM)
usage is concerned.

Happy easter to you as well,
   Wolf DL4YHF.

column21:
Hi Wolf,
the > 2000 callsign entries are not buffered in memory. It is more the PoC that lastheard.c routines using new buffers like slog_lines[SMAXLINES] and clog_lines[CMAXLINES], which have been introduced and used by netmon5+6, are defined and refererenced in a proper way and buffer clear routines working correctly.
Happy easter to all, vy 73
Mike, DL2MF

column21:
Hi Mike,

I am just trying to understand some of the changes. What gives me
headaches is the modified "print_time_hook()". If this is really one of
the hooked functions (that are supposed to replace something, i.e. "hook
into" the original firmware), we must be extremely careful with the
function arguments. You modified it to take a "char *log" as function
argument, but compare "log" with a single character (not a char-pointer)
inside the function.
Very wrong (in print_time_hook) :
 if ( log == 'c' )
because you declared "log" as a char-pointer (I'd name it cpLog or even
pszLog (*) for that reason, but using data type prefixes is an almost
religious thing.. some like it, some hate it.)
(*) psz = pointer to a string with a zero-terminator, as a matter of taste

Besides that, the old problem with the non-functional netmon keys still
remains here, on an RT3 bought last december, which runs the
"D13.020"-based firmware without other problems. Do you have a readily
compiled+linked firmware image for comparison ? I have the impression
that this may be related with the build-tools used here (which I will
*not* change another time).

Cheers,
   Wolf .

‚Ä¶

 Hi @DL2MF <https://github.com/DL2MF>, @travisgoodspeed
 <https://github.com/travisgoodspeed>

 On MD380 (without GPS) - Date format - The is no blue button as other
 menus, also if chose TalkerAlias it just gives date and time.

 Maybe something different between GPS/No GPS firmware?

 Paulo - CT2JAY

column21:
@paulo - CT2JAY:
The dot marker is missing in MD380Tools in all submenus with more than 4 entries, there is a bug in the submenu routines. Wolf, DL4YHF did already open an issue to this about 2 months ago, so nothing that is depending on latest changes.
You have to press "Confirm", the selection is being confirmed by message and then written to the radio config in memory. No matter of MD380/390 or with/without GPS.
73 Mike, DL2MF

key "0" - netmon6 - channel LH list, shows, where activity was received (helpful on longer monitoring)
2017-02-25:

solving build issue with D02.032 in netmon.c

2017-02-24:

solving all merge conflicts and returning to legacy keyb layout

2017-02-18:

add talker alias option to date format submenu (additionally to alt status)
show talker alias on status line if received valid info
display users.csv entry with talker alias in name info (line below callsign & name)
The Zero-key "Null" will null/clear the syslog, other keys swapped remain in the same function blocks without unintentional causing a function or deleting something.

2017-02-17:

New netmon5 shows mixed channel name (when channel changes) / lastheard calls / lh page count
New netmon6 shows last channels with activities (to give you an idea where your lastheard were RX)
Fixed typo in addl_config.c (md380_create_main_menu_entry)
Organized all backlight settings in a seperate submenu in md380tools menu instead of 3 main entries

column13: added menu option to set the talkgroup
column20:
Intent of the changes:
Allow the operator to enter an arbitrary talkgroup number, and replace the talkgroup for the current channel with the entry.  This allows arbitrary talkgroups to be joined on Brandmeister and similar repeaters.  In contrast, using the "manual dial" functionality in the baseline firmware's menu allows only private calls.  To join a talkgroup, the destination id must be a group id.  This modification accomplishes that.
Implementation:
Two new functions in menu.c:
void create_menu_entry_set_tg_screen_store(void)
void create_menu_entry_set_tg_screen(void)
These functions add a new menu item to set the talkgroup of the current channel using numeric entry.  The code is mostly copied from the edit_dmr_id functions, but the entry is placed into the appropriate nibbles of the extern contact structure.  Writing to the appropriate tg address is accomplished using a copy of the code from the copy_dst_to_contact() function in keyb.c.
The current talkgroup is loaded into the edit buffer.  A change must be confirmed then the new talkgroup is loaded for use.
I am happy to accept any comments regarding the form or function of this code.
Thanks for the opportunity to contribute to this project.
73,
K0BJR

column21:
Hi Brad (and all)

you wrote:
 But, I've already fixed it. I'm a bit of a noob wrt github. Shall I
 submit a new pull request?

A difficult question, I cannot answer it completely (being a github noob
myself, only used version control dinosaurs so far). If the previous PR
isn't merged yet, it's no problem (I don't think Github "takes a
snapshot" of your branch in the second you pull the request. When it's
time to merge, the maintainer of the master (travisgoodspeed/md380tools)
will pull the modifications from *your* up-to-date repository.
Just make sure your own repo (on Github) is sync'd with the files on
your harddisk.

The question is often when to pull a 'brand-new' request, because it
causes a lot of work to the maintainers.
The less time it took between creation of your own ("temporary") branch,
committing it to your own repo, and pulling a merge-request for it, the
less work it will be for the maintainers to merge it because there are
only a few modifications (ideally).
But if other 'merging activities' are currently taking place, your
(pending) branch is getting older, and more difficult to merge unless
you keep it synced with Travis' master. (This can be done in the 'Github
desktop' thingy; I guess if 'Update from travisgoodspeed/master' is
grayed out,  there's "nothing to do").

So for my part, I keep developing further even if an own PR may still be
pending. And even if it's still pending, I commit changes to *my*
repository so others can see what I'm currently working on, and (if
anyone really cares and spend the time) can try out the modifications
*before* there's a pull-request for them.

Anyway, Murphy's law ensures that errors are discovered shortly *after*
committing / pulling requests / having them merged. Been there,
regretted it, what else can you do ? ;o)

At the moment there are two PRs pending, one of them for some time
already. I just withdrew mine (which btw was for issue #704, reduce the
number of compiler warnings)  to avoiding possible merge conflicts. When
the pending ones are merged, I simply sync my temporary branch from
Travis' master again, and (eventually) pull a new PR.


Short form: IMHO, just let your PR pend (since you don't want your
addition to 'vanish') . If there are significant changes on Travis's
master, merge them into your own branch to check for conflicts yourself.
Keep committing to our branch (in "small documented steps") regardless
of a PR pending or not.


Cheers,
   Wolf .

After the first PTT on the new tg it will appear in the netmon screen however.

Writing to the appropriate tg address is accomplished using a copy of the code from the copy_dst_to_contact() function in keyb.c.
The current talkgroup is loaded into the edit buffer.  A change must be confirmed then the new talkgroup is loaded for use.
I am happy to accept any comments regarding the form or function of this code.
Thanks for the opportunity to contribute to this project.
73,

column21:
Wolf (and all interested),

I'd like to get your thoughts on menu hooks and the menu drawing
internals.  I've been working to expose the set_tg_id functionality in the
set sidebutton menu using an appropriate case in keyb.c. Here's what I've
learned (these things are likely very obvious to you and other developers).
‚Ä¶
-The menu structure gets built every time the "Menu" button is pressed.
Prior to the first press, it does not exist.  Therefore any calls to draw a
submenu directly must build the structure first.  I can built the
addl_functions menus but can't find a hook or calling sequence to build the
full menu structure.
-Simply setting gui_opmode1 to  SCR_MODE_MENU and calling the function
specified in the submenu creation is not enough, there are other screen
rendering operations that are executed as part of the normal menu traversal
that are skipped when I do this.  The result is that some of the menu
elements are drawn, but others are not.  It is not usable.
-There probably a very hackish way to use some stateful logic the the rtc
code to simulate the button presses and get to the menu, but it seems like
an awful route.

Any info you can offer is greatly appreciated.

Brad

column21:
Hello Brad and all,

By chance, I am also trying to understand more details about the menu
internals (btw to report the currently focused, or currently selected
menu item in Morse code). For the button lists it works, but not for
Tytera's main menu, and several submenus opened from there.
Some time ago I accidentally found the C sources of what *may* be an
older version of the GUI that has been used in the Tytera software. It's
a grandfather of EmWin (and the stuff that ST offer for their CPUs, very
unfortunately only as a compiled library). But this one includes the
full C sources which may helpful for understanding the details:
https://github.com/fazibear/Misa-Kitara-AP

The huge zip contains embedded operating system for a futuristic (kind
of) electronic guitar, including a GUI based on Segger's/Micrium's
uC/GUI, which years later evolved into ST's "STEmWin" (or whatever the
name is now). I didn't study the sources of this old uC/GUI  (Version
3.98) yet. On a short glance, it contains a lot of low-level and high
level graphic stuff, including fonts, menus, radio-button widgets, etc.
Because it's over 6 years old, there may be large differences between
this and the MD380 firmware.

If you're interested, start grokking at GUI/Core/GUI.h .
For example, GUI_CONTEXT has some similarities with "our" gfx_...
structures.
With some luck, we may be able to spot similarities also in the 'Widget'
directory (especially "MENU.c", "SCROLLBAR.c", "RADIO.c", "CHECKBOX.c",
"EDIT_xyz.c" ).

Maybe time to look into this again ? Trying to understand the
disassembled code is extremely time-consuming (at least for me, despite
being familiar with C and ARM), and whenever I look at it, I am deeply
impressed by the work that Travis and others have already invested to
find out how this 'blackbox' works.

Have a nice weekend,
   Wolf .

column21:
Hello Brad,

Maybe your TG extension is a good candidate for the new 'app menu',
which is completely under our control because it uses none of the
original firmware's menu- and graphics functions.
In other words, we can invoke that menu anytime we want, and inside it,
can do anything we want (navigate through lists, show menu items and
their current values, edit them 'in line', or draw complete custom
screens). It is opened from the main screen with the red "back" button
(which has no function on the original main screen). The "Set TG"
feature would be one of the first items in the new menu opened that way.
It still lacks support for drawing bitmaps in Tytera's format, but imho
it's better suited (and faster) than fiddling around with Tytera's
origninal menu.
Since (at the moment) I am the only one familiar with this "new" menu
system, let me first finish the method for direct alphanumeric input
(when a menu item is in "edit" mode). The Set TG feature will be easy to
use, and faster to invoke than when buried deeply in the original menu.

I will pull a merge request for it soon, even though I am still working
on the new modules (app_menu.c for the menu framework, lcd_driver.c for
the own, much faster LCD driver). At the moment, this is only in my own
fork (dl4yhf/md380tools) on Github.

Cheers,
   Wolf .

column21:
Hi Brad and all,
I have adapted your method for the new 'app menu' now. Seems to work well, even when invoked via programmed sidekey (which would have been a nightmare to implement with the original 'Tytera' menu).
The only problem that remains (at the moment) is how to convince Tytera's main display screen to show the modified tx-talkgroup above the off-hook phone icon. But that's more or less a cosmetic issue.
There's an early draft of a description at http://www.qsl.net/dl4yhf/RT3/index.html#ad_hoc_talkgroup .

The current talkgroup is loaded into the edit buffer.  A change must be confirmed then the new talkgroup is loaded for use.
I am happy to accept any comments regarding the form or function of this code.
Thanks for the opportunity to contribute to this project.
73,
K0BJR

column13: added menu option to set the talkgroup
column20:
Intent of the changes:
Allow the operator to enter an arbitrary talkgroup number, and replace the talkgroup for the current channel with the entry.  This allows arbitrary talkgroups to be joined on Brandmeister and similar repeaters.  In contrast, using the "manual dial" functionality in the baseline firmware's menu allows only private calls.  To join a talkgroup, the destination id must be a group id.  This modification accomplishes that.
Implementation:
Two new functions in menu.c:
void create_menu_entry_set_tg_screen_store(void)
void create_menu_entry_set_tg_screen(void)
These functions add a new menu item to set the talkgroup of the current channel using numeric entry.  The code is mostly copied from the edit_dmr_id functions, but the entry is placed into the appropriate nibbles of the extern contact structure.  Writing to the appropriate tg address is accomplished using a copy of the code from the copy_dst_to_contact() function in keyb.c.
The current talkgroup is loaded into the edit buffer.  A change must be confirmed then the new talkgroup is loaded for use.
I am happy to accept any comments regarding the form or function of this code.
Thanks for the opportunity to contribute to this project.
73,
K0BJR

column21:
Hi Travis and all,

I don't think merging this PR will delay anything. Except for the
"const" specified (which I will add in my own branch now to avoid future
trouble), the prototype / declaration of print_time_hook would be the
same as PR #726 .

What I am still  (a bit) concerned about is this:
Since "print_time_hook" looks like one of the special functions designed
to replace something in the original firmware,
will THE ORIGINAL FIRMWARE call it from somewhere ? If it did, it would
hardly pass in a 'char' as a function argument in register R0, and the
content of R0 (= char log) would be unpredictable then.
In other words: If print_time_hook replaces a function of the original
firmware, we should not change the function's argument list at all.
Well, I didn't have the time to look it up in the symbol file or in the
disassembled original firmware yet, to examine the call stack for
print_time_hook() .


Cheers,
   Wolf .

column13: Morse output for visually impaired hams
column20:
.. plus an 'alternative' menu supposed to be easier to use, less deeply nested, and the most important item-VALUES are immediately visible ( / readable in Morse code) without the need to enter a submenu or extra dialog / "confirm" screen.
May become the framework to open Netmon screens. Already allows entering an 'ad-hoc' talkgroup number on the fly (also via programmable sidekey, based on PR #708), without entering Tytera's menu. Similar planned (with a whitesticker-friendly user interface) also to enter an ad-hoc reflector number.
Unresolved issue with interference from channel scanning: During a message in Morse code, the audio PA must be enabled. If, during that time, channels are scanned, there's a hell of a noise originating from the demodulator (or DMR chip). Still looking for a way to temporarily disable channel scanning without turning it off in the config.
Take your time with merging - this branch isn't fully finished and will possibly take a few weeks until other plans (by DL4YHF) have been put into the code.

The alternative ("Morse-output-friendly") menu is making good progress.
Turns out a nice way to edit the talkgroup ad-hoc, and can be flawlessly invoked from any programmable sidebutton. All credits to Brad for PR #708; I have 'assimilated' his pending PR in mine.
The in-place editor (which allows editing any numeric value in the menu) needs some polishing, but will be finished / published soon.
If anyone else is also working on the 'Set Talkgroup via sidebutton' feature : Let's coordinate this here, don't  re-invent the wheel. Ok ?
73, Wolf .

Github is driving me crazy. It shows sooo many merge conflicts where just trivial modifications were made (I cannot fix or resolve those merge-conflicts myself because I don't have write-permission to the original master, even for those modules I wrote myself like irq_handlers.c ! ).
I give up. This automatic 'merge conflict detection' is just TOO PEDANTIC. For example, it refuses to merge a module in which a broken indentation (caused by the use of dreadful TAB characters) has been fixed by replacing dreadful tabs with spaces to make them readable in any editor (regardless of the tab settings).
Please delete this PR. I will try to create a new branch from the current master (travisgoodspeed), and try to merge everything. Or, maybe, I will maintain my own fork from now on. That may be easier (for everyone involved !) than merging a branch based on a two-month old repository, and having to do this over and over again.

column21:
The way GitHub resolves merge conflicts on the website is by merging the target branch into the submitted branch and having you resolve those conflicts. So, if you want to merge the branch feature into master and there are conflicts, it will have you merge master into feature then merge the result of that into master.
I would recommend merging from git directly. To do this you need to have travisgoodepeed/md380tools cloned and add your fork as another remote (git remote add Wolf-DL4YHF https://github.com/Wolf-DL4YHF/md380tools.git). To get the latest updates from your fork, run git fetch Wolf-DL4UFH.
To merge:

Ensure you have the latest changes for the branch that you want to merge into (travisgoodepeed/md380tools@master)
git checkout master
git pull
Get the latest changes from your branch
`git fetch Wolf-DL4YHF'
Do the merging
git merge --no-ff Wolf-DL4YHF/master
This should list files where it had conflicts.
Fix the conflicts
Use git status to see what files have conflicts; these will be listed under Unmerged paths:.
Once you have fixed the conflicts in a file, mark it as resolved by running git add <path to file>.
If you want to restore the state of a file to when you started the merge (a mistake was made when resolving the conflicts), run git checkout -m <path to file>.
Finish merging
Run git commit to finish the merge.
To push the results to travisgoodepeed/md380tools run git push.

If, during that time, channels are scanned, there's a hell of a noise originating from the demodulator (or DMR chip). Still looking for a way to temporarily disable channel scanning without turning it off in the config.
Take your time with merging - this branch isn't fully finished and will possibly take a few weeks until other plans (by DL4YHF) have been put into the code.
column21:
Hi there,
Thanks for the info. Basically this is what I had been using in earlier
development steps, but this time, I got flooded with merge conflicts
which (to me) didn't make sense at all. Well, most of them have been
fixed in the meantime.

Looks there were just too many subsequent changes, all of them
documented very frequently by myself (for each and every module written
in the meantime, related with the Morse output and the new, alternative
'text mode' menu).

I simply cloned the main repository again, and synchronized the files
with my local repository (DL4YHF branch) with the 'fresh' main
repository. This also reduced the size of the zipped repository from
almost 80 MByte to about 54 MByte. The revision history of my own
changes got lost this way (but of course not the revision history of
other contributors). So far, no more merge conflicts, and even the
'Travis CI' build processed finished flawlessly with both build
environments. Sigh..

Anyway, I deleted the old PR (#734 with many dozens of small
modifications) and replaced it by PR #741 which should be easier to
merge. There's a minor thing left to do (related with the codeplug
structure used inside the SPI flash, which I cannot validate for GPS
devices / S13.020), but that's another topic.

All the best,
   Wolf .

Am 08.05.2017 um 02:10 schrieb Schuyler St. Leger:
‚Ä¶

 The way GitHub resolves merge conflicts on the website is by merging
 the target branch into the submitted branch and having you resolve
 those conflicts. So, if you want to merge the branch |feature| into
 |master| and there are conflicts, it will have you merge |master| into
 |feature| then merge the result of that into |master|.

 I would recommend merging from git directly. To do this you need to
 have |travisgoodepeed/md380tools| cloned and add your fork as another
 remote (|git remote add
 https://github.com/Wolf-DL4YHF/md380tools.git|). To get the latest
 updates from your fork, run |git fetch Wolf-DL4UFH|.

 To merge:

   * Ensure you have the latest changes for the branch that you want to
     merge into ***@***.***)
     |git checkout master|
     |git pull|
   * Get the latest changes from your branch
     `git fetch Wolf-DL4YHF'
   * Do the merging
     |git merge --no-ff Wolf-DL4YHF/master|
     This should list files where it had conflicts.
   * Fix the conflicts
     Use |git status| to see what files have conflicts; these will be
     listed under |Unmerged paths:|.
     Once you have fixed the conflicts in a file, mark it as resolved
     by running |git add <path to file>|.
     If you want to restore the state of a file to when you started the
     merge (a mistake was made when resolving the conflicts), run |git
     checkout -m <path to file>|.
   * Finish merging
     Run |git commit| to finish the merge.
     To push the results to |travisgoodepeed/md380tools| run |git push|.

 ‚Äî

column13: Fix for issue #712, cleanup of keyb.
column20:
The reported defect (#712: 'Menu Button Stops Working With Experimental "ON"') was isolated to a change to keyb.c made in commit fdc839e ("allow calling up the menu induring rx").
The problem is two-fold:

The code does not actually work for the stated purpose (as the comment in the commit indicates).
The conditional guarding the code allows it to execute outside of the condition it was crafted for (aka: it triggers regardless of the idle/rx state of the radio).

Fixing problem 1 will require more thought.  This commit fixes problem 2 by limiting the execution of this code to when the radio is in the rx state.
While investigating the behavior in this code path, I performed some cleanup in the form of creating symbolic constants for the keycodes.  This reduces the number of magic numbers in the file, but not all of them.

column20:
This is the minimal fix for issue #645 .  Before this fix, there were only two places where a corrupted file could show up:

From a curl download that fails without an error code
md380-fw generating a corrupted file

The other recipes in the firmware directory all check the size of the target and delete it and fail if there is a mismatch.  This minimal fix fills gap number 1 from above with a simple check for greater than zero bytes.

column13: Changed ci to error on compiler warnings
column20:
This commit is an attempt to stop the inflow of new warnings being added to the applet, while avoiding having to resolve all the #warning directives already in the codebase.
With this change, regular builds are unaffected; they will proceed as they have in the past.  "make ci", however, will promote warnings to errors, but #warnings will be suppressed altogether.  The end result of this will be to make the ci fail when someone introduces a new warning to the applet.
This commit may warrant the closing of issue #704.

column21:
The last CI failure was:

https://archive.org/download/TYTMD380FW2/MD280.002.018.bin => dl/MD280.002.018.bin
make[6]: *** [dl/MD280.002.018.bin] Error 52

Error 52 from curl is CURLE_GOT_NOTHING.  According to the curl docs this means:

Nothing was returned from the server, and under the circumstances, getting nothing is considered an error.

I believe this was a transient error, as all the previous image downloads were successful and local attempts to download MD280.002.018.bin work as expected.  I'll add --retry to the curl invocation to make this code path more resilient to transient failures.

column21:
Hi @KD4Z,
Thanks for the feedback.  I went with a simple "--retry 3" because of my impression that archive.org is typically pretty responsive, but occasionally will send back an empty file.  I'm a little concerned about the --max-time 60 in your proposal as it may cause the download to fail unnecessarily for people with slow internet access.
That said, it would be nice to have a standard curl invocation across the whole project.

column21:
I wouldn't worry too much about the max time being 60.  That  is actually the part that makes it work.  The retry by itself wasn't enough.  When the download completes, it exits before the max time value.    I can clearly see it linger up to 15 seconds when testing on a 3G wifi hotspot, and my users in Europe are seeing it grow to over 30 seconds now.    I actually have my VM running at 180 right now!  Execessive?  Maybe, but the script is a total fail if the download doesn't come in so might as well give it a few more seconds to try and finish.
I agree about the standard values across the scripts, but thats another story :)
Warren, KD4Z

column13: Minor changes for Morse output and application-menu (aka "red button menu")
column20:
Morse output can be activated by blind OMs by holding the red BACK key pressed during power-on. An info message is displayed for this.
Added a stub to invoke Netmon screens from the new application-menu aka "red-button menu".
Still lacks the ability to scroll through the long list of Lastheard-entry, which would be nice to have with the fast LCD driver and autorepeat. But the necessary FIFO-variables and buffer sizes are not exposed in lastheard.h, etc, which I don't want to modify before I know exactly how they are supposed to work :o)

column20: Wrap scrolling for the app menu. When at the top and pressing up the menu will continue to the bottom. At the bottom, it will wrap to the top. This also wraps the scrolling of the zone chooser in the app menu.
column21: Wrap scrolling for the app menu. When at the top and pressing up the menu will continue to the bottom. At the bottom, it will wrap to the top. This also wraps the scrolling of the zone chooser in the app menu.

column20: Wrap scrolling for the app menu. When at the top and pressing up the menu will continue to the bottom. At the bottom, it will wrap to the top. This also wraps the scrolling of the zone chooser in the app menu.
column21:
Thanks, this is a convenient modification.
I thought about adding a circular wrap for the menu item index myself, and was a bit concerned about this:
For a blind operator, it was easy to scroll to the end or the top of the list by simply holding the cursor down/up key pressed for some time, and let the autorepeat do the rest.
But there will be a method to jump to a certain item by entering its index numerically in the next release, so this is not an issue anymore.
Cheers,  Wolf .

column13: Disable Hotkeys When App Menu Is Open
column20: When the app menu is open this disables the hotkeys. Without this, using the app menu can result in unknowingly transmitting (1 button) or clearing logs (5 button).

column13: Fix for backlight and non-functional "red key menu" for KD4Z VM
column20:
The previous version only worked properly when compiled on a freshly installed 64-bit Debian system, and on 64-bit Windows using MinGW. No other platforms tested here yet.
The previous version failed to open the red menu when compiled in the KD4Z Virtual Machine.
Why these "building platforms" produce different binary code (confirmed by the map file) still has to be found out. Maybe the GNU ARM toolchain behaves differently on 32- and 64-bit systems (hard to believe... but that's what it looked like).
This release has a temporary(!) feature to check if the hooked SysTick handler is invoked in the patched firmware at all:  Between 5 and 20 seconds after power-on, the GREEN LED will give very short (and thus weak) flashes, once every 256 * 1.5 milliseconds. When successfully tested on KD4Z VM, this LED-flashing feature will be removed again (it's in irq_handlers.c, and can be easily commented out when not required anymore).

Sigh... still this only works properly when compiled on 64-bit Debian, Windows, but not when compiled inside the KD4Z Virtual Machine.
Only the green LED (which flashes faintly for a short time after power-on) confirms that the hooked SysTick_Handler is being called. Thus the patch applied inside the VM (when running "glv") works, but something else is missing.

Edit: It is possible to compile this into a fully functional non-GPS firmware with the KD4Z VM, but not by issuing the simple "glv" command in the menu. Some old files remaining somewhere inside the VM's tyt/md380tools directory ? See Issue #755, date 2017-05-20 .
No problems seen when cloning this repository into a clean folder on 64-bit Debian (even in another VM) or on 64-bit Windows.

column21:
Beware, your addition in SysTick_Handler may be unsafe.
You added a new keyboard-polling function, called from SysTick_Handler, which in turn calls ...
PollKeysForScroll -> ..... -> handle_hotkey().
handle_hotkey() seems to draw something on the screen (clog_redraw), changes gui_opmode1 + 2, etc.
Since SysTick_Handler() is called 666 times per seconds, and we can expect that it may be called from "anywhere". It also interrupts the currently running task (and that may be "anything").
Setting a flag in SysTick_Handler is ok, but anything that possibly takes several milliseconds must not be done there.
Such problems won't happen immediately. But sooner or later a SysTick (interrupt) will fire when you don't expect it, and .... "bang". That why anything else in irq_handlers.c pedantically avoids calling anything that may call something in the original firmware, of course except the original SysTick_Handler.

column21:
Thanks for your advice, did you experience any issues or notice any unreasonable inconsistency?
This build has been tested very in-depth and you might have noticed, that PollKeysForScroll() is being called every 111th SysTick, what is far enough for cursor scrolling. Due to my awareness I already made several very huge scrolling tests to check for timing issues, for instance continuously scrolling within menus (not only MD380tools menu), contacts, zones several hundred times, with stucked keys, without and for several minutes, as long as my finger could press the keys.
This firmware is running since a week on my two MD-390/G and a MD-446, both types very extensively in use and currently all radios are working fine, also when in use for > 10h a day.
My latest pull request now also includes the user-selectable keyb layout for MD-3x0/MD-446 inside the option menu, no need any more to compile separately firmware for the MD-446. This might also be a lookahead for upcoming new models supported by MD380tools.

column21:
Hi Mike,


you might have noticed, that PollKeysForScroll() is being called every 111th SysTick


Of course, but it doesn't matter. Even if only every 111 th SysTick calls a function in the original firmware that isn't re-entrant, or runs in a task that isn't designed to be called from anywhere else, your're asking for trouble.

column13: Use ${MAKE} for sub-makes rather than make.
column20:
Some systems (such as FreeBSD) have a different make and install
GNU make as gmake.  For these systems, we must use ${MAKE} instead
of hard-coding make.

column13: Read mfg string before using USB extensions
column20:
This is what triggers hooking the DFU to enable additional commands.
It seems that on Linux at least, this string is read by default, but
at least on FreeBSD, it is not.
If the string is not accessed, the SPI ID is read as garbage and
the additional commands don't work.  Simply accessing it fixes this.
